entry.title: Fra data til indsigter
entry.summary: 👋 Hej, jeg hedder Kiril, og velkommen til MindGraph: min lille, privatejede konsulentsfirma, som er specialiseret i at hjælpe dig…
entry.content:
👋 Hej, jeg hedder Kiril, og velkommen til MindGraph: min lille, privatejede konsulentsfirma, som er specialiseret i at hjælpe dig med at omdanne dine data til  indsigter, som du kan handle på. Jeg brænder for at finde sammenhænge i data samt bistå beslutningstagere med praktiske, databaserede anbefalinger.

Få hjælp med dit projekt

Uanset om det drejer sig om at definere og afgrænse projekter, skabe ETL pipelines og BI rapporter eller udvikle prædiktive modeller, mit kendskab spreder sig over en bred vifte af datarelaterede opgaver.

Her er nogle af de områder, hvorpå jeg kan bidrage:

For at se hvordan jeg har brugt mine evner i helt praktiske projekte, tag gerne et kig på nogle af de projekter, jeg har arbejdet på indtil videre:

I disse projekter har jeg nemlig været med til alt fra start til slut, dvs. at jeg både har indsalmet, renset og analyseret på dataene samt formidlet de endelige indisgter i menneskesprog.

Udforsk dine datas potentiale

Data er næsten aldrig perfekt, men det skal ikke forhindre os i at finde værdifulde indsigter i dem. Ved at kombinere din domæneviden og min dataekspertise kan vi teste dine hypoteser i praksis, fremhæve vigtige konklusioner og lave konkrete anbefalinger, som du kan handle på.

Kontakt mig venligst på kirilboyanovbg@gmail.com for et gratis og uforpligtende møde på 30 minutter, hvor vi kan diskutere dine behov og vores mulige samarbejde i forbindelse med dit projekt.

entry.title: Contact
entry.summary: If you have a potential project you'd like to discuss, we can arrange a free 30 minutes online meeting where…
entry.content:
If you have a potential project you'd like to discuss, we can arrange a free 30 minutes online meeting where we can talk about your needs and requirements and where we can align our expectations.

  • Email: if you'd like to make an inquiry, it's best to drop me a message at kirilboyanovbg@gmail.com.
  • LinkedIn: you're also welcome to contact me via a private message. You can find my LinkedIn profile here.
  • GitHub: my GitHub page contains demos of some of the projects I've worked on in my spare time. Feel free to explore and get an idea of what I'd be able to do for you.

entry.title: From data to insight
entry.summary: 👋 Hello, my name is Kiril and welcome to MindGraph: my small, privately-owned consultancy specialised in helping you leverage your…
entry.content:
👋 Hello, my name is Kiril and welcome to MindGraph: my small, privately-owned consultancy specialised in helping you leverage your data by transforming it into actionable insights. I am passionate about finding patterns in the data and providing decision-makers with practical, data-driven recommendations.

Get help with your project

Whether it's scoping projects, creating data ETL pipelines and BI reports, or developing predictive models, my expertise spans a broad spectrum of data-related services.

Here are some of the areas I cover:

To see how I've applied my skills in real-life situations, feel free to explore some of the projects I've worked on in the past:

In these projects, I've taken care of the whole process from sourcing and cleaning the data to analysing it and communicating the insights in layman terms.

Unlock the potential of your data

Data is almost never perfect, but that doesn't deter me from using it to extract valuable insights. By combining your domain knowledge and my data expertise, we can test your hypotheses in practice, highlight important conclusions and recommend actions to address pressing challenges.

Please reach out to me at kirilboyanovbg@gmail.com for a free, no-strings-attached 30 minutes meeting where we can discuss your needs and do some initial project scoping.

entry.title: Services
entry.summary: During my 5+ years of full-time experience, I've had the opportunity to work on a wide variety of tasks spanning…
entry.content:
During my 5+ years of full-time experience, I've had the opportunity to work on a wide variety of tasks spanning from data collection, transformation and analysis to presenting insights and onboarding users to interactive tools and reports. The various roles I've held have thought me the importance of relating data to a business context, tailoring analyses and reports to the end user's needs as well as how best to support non-technical people in getting the most out of the tools I've built.

On this page, you can read more about what services I offer and the kinds of data I'm most experienced with.

What can I do for you?

Some of the areas in which I can help you include:

  • Data extract, transform and load (ETL) project scoping
  • Business Intelligence (BI) & reporting project scoping
  • Analytics/data science project scoping
  • Development of ETL processes (R, Python, Power Query, SQL)
  • Data collection from structured and unstructured sources and data clean-up (R, Python, SQL)
  • Creating, publishing and onboarding users to Power BI reports
  • Creating, publishing and onboarding users to Streamlit data apps (Python)
  • Conducting statistical analyses, including presentation and communication of results (R, Python)
  • Developing statistical/ML predictive models, including presentation and communication of method, result and implications (R, Python)

What data have I worked with?

So far in my career, I've had my hands on a wide variety of data such as:

  • Personal data (HR-related)
  • Educational data
  • Macroeconomic data
  • Political data
  • Pricing data
  • Cross-sectional data
  • Time series data

Common for all of the above is that the data is never perfect. However, it is my conviction that that should never prevent us from using to derive some insights! A proper data clean-up and making some sensible assumptions, combined with a clearly defined question you want to find an answer to go a long way to facilitating a good analytics product.

entry.title: About
entry.summary: MindGraph started in 2024 as a part-time endeavour, a place to collect various projects I've worked on in the past…
entry.content:
MindGraph started in 2024 as a part-time endeavour, a place to collect various projects I've worked on in the past and to explore the possibilities of partnering with other companies and individuals who are interested in leveraging data to better understand and act on what's on their mind.

On this page, I describe the mission and vision of Mindsight. If you're interested in the details, you can explore my areas of expertise here.

Mission

My mission is to contribute to a better world by facilitating a deeper understanding of the patterns and phenomena that shape our reality. I am committed to providing decision-makers with practical recommendations based on a solid data foundation. By harnessing my curiosity, dedication, and perseverance, I tackle real-world data challenges, extract meaningful insights, and communicate them in a user-friendly, accessible manner.

Vision

I envision a future where data-driven insights empower decision-makers at all levels, fostering informed choices that lead to a better, more equitable world. To arrive there, I believe we need to reshape the way working with data and analytics is perceived, transforming it from a complex, challenging endeavour into something more relatable and accessible for the average human being. Data-driven insights can help us change the world for the better - provided that we are all on board with the story the data is trying to tell us.

entry.title: World happiness study
entry.summary: Do you know what the world’s happiest country is? (Spoiler alert: it’s somewhere in the Nordics.) Each year, the World…
entry.content:
Do you know what the world’s happiest country is? (Spoiler alert: it’s somewhere in the Nordics.) Each year, the World Happiness Report (WHR) gives an account of the state of happiness around the world. More often than not, its findings are not that surprising: highly developed countries with stable political systems are on top, while poor and war-torn countries are relegated to the bottom.

In this project (which I worked on between April 2023 - January 2024), I delved into the data to explore how happiness scores have evolved over time and identify the key factors that impact national happiness. Then, I used this knowledge to predict countries’ happiness scores for 2023-2024 before the WHR has even collected the data! Below, I present some of my findings but I strongly encourage you to download my infographic so as not to miss on any of the insights.

Happiness is on a downwards trajectory

People around the world are now less happy than they were roughly two decades ago, with global happiness showing a decline of 14% in the period 2005-2022, as shown on the chart below:

The the largest decline in happiness was observed in countries which have had very dire economic circumstances and/or military conflicts such as Afghanistan, Lebanon and Venezuela, while the largest improvement was seen in several African and Eastern European countries.

Happiness reflects development and governance

National happiness is largely defined by how well developed and how well governed a country is. Accounting for various economic, political, social, environmental and health-related factors, it is possible to explain up to 74% of the differences in happiness scores between countries over time.

I arrived at this conclusion by testing a series of ridge-regression models, where the best fitting model contained a total of 27 factors. Out of these, the ones with the strongest relative impact on global happiness were GDP per capita, female unemployment rate, access to electricity, health expenditure per capita and corruption. Other factors with a sizeable effect on happiness are shown below:

Future happiness can be predicted accurately

Over the past 17 years, Denmark has consistently ranked among the top 3 happiest countries, a feat it has achieved an impressive 16 times. Many of the other countries which appear on top of the list have also consistenly ranked high on happiness across time. Given these strong historical trends, I decided to explore how the state of happiness is going to look for in the next couple of years, assuming the underlying factors that determine national happiness remain unchanged.

To do so, I developed a machine learning model (random forest) to generate the predictions.The model was trained on all years except for the most recent year with available happiness score (2022) and was optimised to increase its accuracy. The input variables included in the model, which were selected based on the ridge regression analysis, did not originally have values in future time periods, so those were derived by projecting historical trends into the future. Assuming country-level historical trends remain valid in the forecasting period, the model should be able to predict national happiness scores with an accuracy of up to 96%.

According to this model, the top 10 happiest countries in 2023 should be:

  1. Finland (predicted happiness score: 7.65)
  2. Denmark (7.61)
  3. Switzerland (7.43*)
  4. Iceland (7.43)
  5. Norway (7.43)
  6. Sweden(7.28)
  7. Netherlands (7.27)
  8. Luxembourg (7.17)
  9. Austria (7.16)
  10. New Zealand (7.05)

Similarly, the top 10 happiest countries in 2024 should be:

  1. Denmark (predicted happiness score: 7.62)
  2. Finland (7.57)
  3. Switzerland (7.40)
  4. Iceland (7.38)
  5. Norway (7.28)
  6. Luxembourg (7.19)
  7. Austria (7.15)
  8. Netherlands (7.14)
  9. Sweden (7.06)
  10. Australia (7.02)

Of course, those are just projections based on the assumptions that historical trends for happiness score and its underlying factors will continue into the future. Therefor, it’ll be exciting to see how accurate these predictions prove to be once the actual rankings are released!

🔎📈 Explore the full analysis on the project's GitHub page.

📊📖 Download the infographic with all the insights here.

* Note: the numbers in here have been rounded off to two decimals but in reality, more decimal points are available and the countries have been sorted according to the original, unrounded numbers.

Page cover image source: www.pixabay.com

entry.title: Rentals in the Greater Copenhagen area
entry.summary: If you've ever been looking for a place to stay in the Greater Copenhagen area (Storkøbenhavn), you probably know that…
entry.content:
If you've ever been looking for a place to stay in the Greater Copenhagen area (Storkøbenhavn), you probably know that the struggle is real. With limited supply and high pricing, finding an accommodation can be a challenging task. Prompted by my personal curiousity on the subject, I decided to look into the data to figure out what is generally available for rent, how much it costs as well as which factors influence the price. In this article, I would like to share some of my findings with you, though I encourage you to download my infographic to get all insights.

Disclaimer: Please note that the conclusions and recommendations presented below are as of February 2023. While I expect these to remain more or less stable due to the structural character of the rental market, some changes may occur.

What's available on the market?

This analysis is based on advertisements scapred from the Danish website www.boligportal.dk, where landlords post about accommodations they have available for rent. These can range from single rooms to apartments and houses.

As of 21 February 2023, there were just over 3,000 rentals listed in the Greater Copenhagen area (Storkøbenhavn in Danish). The vast majority of these were apartments (82%) and single rooms (12%). Rooms were mostly located in the city (⅔ of all rooms), while houses were mostly located in the suburbs (92% of all houses).

Other things worth noting include:

  • Overall, 73% of all accommodations were available for rent for an unlimited time period.
  • When it comes to size, regular houses are the rental type with the largest median area (153 m²), followed by semi-detached houses (120 m²) and apartments (87 m²).
  • If we measure size by the median number of rooms instead, the conclusion is pretty similar, with houses leading (5 rooms), followed by semi-detached (4 rooms) and apartments (3 rooms).
  • Apartments were the type of accommodation most likely to be associate with an unlimited lease duration, while houses were least likely to be available for an unlimited time period, as the chart below shows:

Not sure what’s reasonable to pay for rent?

Looking at the price of rent per square meter, we see that for the vast majority of accommodations, you’d be expected to pay between 150-200 kr. per m². That being said, in some cases the price can be as low as 67 kr. per m² or as high as 894 kr. per m². In 75% of all cases, you can furthermore expect to pay below 13.22 kr. per m² in relation to the monthly fixed acconto payment.

Please note that rent prices differ based on both geographical location and the type of accommodation, as can be seen on the chart below:

Wonder how to save money on rent?

You can use several strategies here. You can either go for a smaller place (if you want to save in absolute terms) or a bigger place (if you want to save in relative terms, given that the price of rent per m² decreases with size). You can also choose a less central location, for example, by opting not to live in Copenhagen or Frederiksberg, you can save 53 kr. per m² on average.

Want to live alone?

If you are single or you just want to live by yourself, then you might be better off by renting a one-room apartment (e.g. a studio) rather than going for a single room in a shared accommodation. Based on median price, one-room apartments are 43% cheaper than single rooms. In fact, if we look at the bottom 75% of all one-room apartments, prices will not exceed 245 kr. per square meter, whereas if we look at the bottom 75% of all single rooms, the price per square meter can be as high as 463 kr. (a difference of 89%).

These are insights from my latest spare time project, where I looked into data on 3,000+ privately rented accommodations from the Danish website BoligPortal. You can read more about the project in the linked infographic and go in-depth with the analysis on my GitHub page.

📊📖 Download the infographic with all the insights here.

🔎📈 Explore the analysis on the project's GitHub page.

Page cover image source: www.pixabay.com
